subject: Re: [junit] Parameterized test when exceptions are expected?

messageBody:
Jason,

Sorry to leave this unanswered for so long. You're right--there's no
way to have the value of the expected attribute on the @Test
annotation vary from parameter to parameter, so your implementation is
as good as I can imagine. Thanks,

David Saff

On 3/12/07, jason r tibbetts <tibbettj@...> wrote:
> Hello,
>
> I'm writing my first JUnit 4.x-style parameterized test case, using a
> tutorial by Ralf Stuckert
> (http://today.java.net/pub/a/today/2006/12/07/junit-reloaded.html) as a
> guide. However, I want to test whether a method throws an exception if
> malformed data is passed in, not that it returns a particular value. Can
> I use a 4.x-style parameterized test case for this, using the (expected
> = Whatever.class) annotations, or does it have to be a 4.1/3.8.1 hybrid
> (where the @Parameters-demarcated method returns a 2D array of args and
> expected exception class types)?
>
> In other words, if I want to parameterize this,
>
> public class FormatTest {
>
> @Test
> public void perfectExample() {
> new Foo("1.2.3");
> }
>
> @Test (expected = FooFormatException.class)
> public void illegalWhitespace() {
> new Foo("1.2 .3");
> }
>
> @Test (expected = FooFormatException.class)
> public void nonIntegerChars() {
> new Foo("1.a.3");
> }
> }
>
> is there a better way to do it than this?
>
> @RunWith (value = Parameterized.class)
> public class FormatTest {
>
> private String arg;
> private Class exClass;
>
> public FormatTest(String arg, Class exceptionClass) {
> this.arg = arg;
> this.exClass = exceptionClass;
> }
>
> @Parameters
> public static Collection data() {
> return Arrays.asList(
> new Object[][] {
> { "1.2.3", null },
> { "1.2. 3", FooFormatException.class },
> { "1.a.3", FooFormatException.class },
> }
> );
> }
>
> @Test
> public void checkConstructorArgs() {
> try {
> new Foo(arg);
> } catch (Exception x) {
> if (exceptionClass != null) {
> assertTrue("Unexpected exception thrown: " + x,
> exClass.isInstance(x));
> }
> }
> }
> }
>
> (p.s. I haven't tried compiling this yet)
>
>
